titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Edgar Laing Heermance Papers
titlestmt.author: compiled by Susan Grigg

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Saturday December 8, 2018 at 08:45

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: Correspondence, printed matter, and writings accumulated through hundreds of inquiries to business and professional associations concerning business ethics and economic planning. Also included is a typescript autobiography spanning his life from childhood through his Minnesota ministry, 1902-1918.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Edgar Laing Heermance Papers (MS 273). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Edgar L. Heermance Papers consist mainly of correspondence, writings, and printed matter accumulated through hundreds of inquiries to business and professional associations about ethics (mainly 1924-1925) and economic planning (mainly ca. 1933). The result is an extraordinary collection of printed codes of ethics and printed and manuscript statements about business plans and practices. Heermance used this material to prepare books on these subjects and then donated it to Yale in 1937. The arrangement is alphabetical by business or profession, as listed on the following pages.
There is also a typescript autobiography of Heermance that spans from his childhood to his ministry in Minnesota.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Edgar L. Heermance received his undergraduate and graduate degrees from Yale (B.A., 1897; M.A., 1899; B.D., 1901). After serving for seventeen years as a minister and frontier missionary in Minnesota, he returned to New Haven in 1919 and devoted himself to study and writing. Beginning in 1936 he was also active in New England forestry, serving as an officer of several trade and environmental organizations. These are his major publications:
1926 -- The Ethics of Business: A Study of Current Standards
1942 -- The Time Stream: A Voyager Takes a Reckoning
The 1897 Yale class books contain excerpts from his letters to the class secretary and more information about his career.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright status for collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

did.unittitle: REAL ESTATE, BUILDING OWNERS AND MANAGERS
TRADE PRACTICE RESEARCH, RELATIONS WITH CHICAGO
TRADE PRACTICE RESEARCH, RELATIONS WITH HARVARD
TRADE PRACTICE RESEARCH, RELATIONS WITH YALE

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: With photographs, letters and memorabilia pasted in.
Included are chapters 3 to 8 of Edgar L. Heermance's autobiography.

The autobiography covers his childhood in White Plains, N.Y., his years at Yale College, from which he graduated in 1897, his marriage to Nora Livingston in 1907 and his ministry in Minnesota, 1902-1918.
